sentence.text: The first boy (patient 1) was delivered normally at 38 weeks 4 days gestation weighing 2.9 kg after an uneventful pregnancy.
He had symmetrical malformations of all four limbs (Figs. 1 and 2).
His forearms were shortened with an inability to supinate or pronate.
His left forearm was held in an overpronated ‘palm outward’ position.
His hands showed an almost symmetrical complicated overlapping syndactyly which included his adducted thumbs.
As a result, the rays of each hand were fused together into confluent masses each with a haphazard arrangement of synostosed metacarpals and phalanges.
Rudimentary dysplastic fused nails were present on the dorsum of each hand.
Similarly, his feet showed symmetrical complex syndactylies involving all the toes with nail fusions present on the right.
His right fourth toe was short and fifth toe laterally deviated.
Radiographs confirmed the presence of bilateral near total radioulnar synostoses and overlapping complex fusions of his metacarpals and phalanges.
Three dimensional computed tomographic (CT) reconstructions were carried out preoperatively to better define potential planes for digital separation.
Within his feet, radiographs showed only four abnormally modelled metatarsals bilaterally, with the fourth and fifth toes both arising from the same abnormally wide fourth metatarsal (Figs. 1 and 2).
A cranial ultrasound and renal ultrasound were normal.
At 6 years of age, patient 1 is felt to have normal learning ability.
His height has been following the ninth percentile.
He has developed a mild thoracic scoliosis (Cobb angle less than 12°) and has been found to have a marked lordosis at the cervical-thoracic junction.
Radiographs have not shown any structural vertebral abnormalities and his hips appear normal.
He has downslanting palpebral fissures and a mild left eyelid ptosis.
The only other medical issue of note is recurrent mild but symptomatic hypoglycaemias, more often when he is unwell, and likely to be ketotic hypoglycaemia.

His baseline investigations for hypoglycaemia showed a normal glucose profile, baseline pituitary functions tests including normal cortisol and growth hormone concentrations (normal growth hormone and cortisol peaks on a glucagon provocation test).

He also had normal baseline bloods and metabolic profile that included acylcarnitines, urine organic acids, plasma amino-acids, very long chain fatty acids, full blood count, urea, creatinine, electrolytes, and liver function tests.
His fast tolerance is up to 15 hours with undetectable insulin levels and adequate generation of fatty acids and ketones which rules out hyperinsulinaemic hypoglycaemia.
He also had normal glucose concentrations on a prolonged oral glucose tolerance test and protein load test.
He has had a slightly low IGF1 of 36 ng/ml (normal range 47–231) with a normal IGFBP3 0f 1.81 mg/L (normal range 1.3–5.6 mg/L).
His most recent height at 6.7 years of age was 113.3 cm (ninth centile), weight 17 kg (second centile) and his current growth velocity is 6 cm/year.
